awd_titl_txt: CISE-MSI: RCBPP-RF: SHF: Towards Efficient, Reliable, and Secure Chaotic Communications in Wearable Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Wearable and portable sensors are finding their way into everyday life, not only as tracking devices but as diagnostic and treatment devices. Wearable wireless devices require efficient secure communication solutions that meet the resource-limited requirements of such devices. To facilitate secure communications for low-power, implantable, portable, or wearable sensors, the encryption process must be integrated directly with the sensor’s underlying hardware. Chaotic circuits can be used to secure communication of resource-limited devices. Chaotic systems are highly complex, unpredictable, and sensitive to their initial condition. However, they can be used to generate predictable responses if certain requirements are met. Chaos can be utilized to hide data under noise, thus providing data confidentiality if used in wireless communication. On the other hand, applications of chaos in secure wireless communication have been limited to laboratory research. Lack of solutions that maintain both ends of communication (transmitter and receiver) synchronized in real-world applications has limited the use of chaotic communication to research laboratories.

To eliminate these issues and provide an efficient, reliable, and secure on-chip chaotic ciphering transmitter and receiver, this research aims to accomplish the following objectives. Phase 1: Delivering a chaotic low-power transmitter and receiver capable of real-time ciphering of sensory signals. Phase 2: Securing the underlying hardware of chaotic communication against piracy and duplication by adopting a provably secure logic locking framework specifically designed for such systems. Phase 3: Developing efficient smart and machine learning algorithms to provide a dynamic matching of the transmitted and received signal. Phase 4: IC prototyping and implementing the design in the physical form to ensure the functionality of the design. This research brings researchers from the Department of Electrical Engineering and Department of Computer Engineering and Computer Science in California State University Long Beach to provide a logic locked transmitter and receiver that can code and decode the signal using chaos in an efficient and reliable manner.

The financial burden of healthcare has been preventing many, most among minorities and underrepresented groups from monitoring their medical condition and seeking treatment. Wearable technology has seen an unprecedented increase in adoption in the last decade and can reduce the cost of healthcare. It can provide accessible care if security is implemented on devices at the design. If such devices are designed with efficient security, the public confidence, and subsequently their adoption, will increase. California State University, Long Beach is a minority serving institute ranked number four for diversity among United States colleges. By engaging diverse students in designing, implementing, and testing secure solutions for wearable health devices, this project aims to expand participation in computing and communication research. Furthermore, secure wearable devices can enhance trust and adoption of such health-monitoring devices and increase access to affordable healthcare and improve health equity.

The general progress of the projects, results, and datasets will be shared publicly through the website and Git repository. The obtained results from this research will be disseminated in the form of publications, technical presentations, design reports, educational materials, dataset, and source code, and will be hosted publicly for the length of this project and beyond, on the investigator's website and Git repository.
The project Git repository: https://github.com/ahedaya/csulb_nsf_cise_msi
The project Website: https://avahedayatipour.com/research/hardwaresecurity

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Overview

This project explored the use of chaotic equations to enhance secure communication and protect hardware systems from potential vulnerabilities. By leveraging advanced mathematical models and innovative hardware designs, the research made significant contributions to secure data transmission and hardware security, addressing key challenges in our rapidly evolving technological landscape.

Major Activities and Objectives

The research was conducted in four primary phases:

Phase 1: Focused on modeling chaotic behaviors through non-linear differential equations, particularly the Lorenz system and its variations. The goal was to use continuous-time chaotic equations to encrypt signals from sensors. Extensive simulations were performed to evaluate the robustness of these systems against noise, synchronization speed, and resistance to process, voltage, and temperature (PVT) variations. The outcomes included a transmitter and receiver system capable of secure synchronization.

Phase 2: Addressed hardware-based security challenges by implementing a logic locking mechanism in chaotic communication circuits using polymorphic and memristor-based designs. These innovations introduced a large key space and resistance to advanced adversarial models, ensuring secure hardware functionality. Practical realization of these systems was achieved through hardware co-simulations using tools like MATLAB Simulink and Xilinx System Generator on FPGA boards.

Phase 3: Machine learning was employed to enhance chaotic encryption's error correction and synchronization. Various machine learning algorithms, including linear regression, k-means clustering, DBSCAN, and Support Vector Machine (SVM), were utilized to reduce decryption errors and improve synchronization metrics. These methods were applied to chaotic communication for wearable devices, highlighting improved error correction and anomaly detection within encrypted messages.

Phase 4: Transitioned from FPGA-based implementations to chip fabrication, marking significant advancements in integrated circuit (IC) design. Activities included designing and synthesizing Chua’s transmitter and receiver circuits in 45nm CMOS technology using Cadence tools. The final design achieved a compact form factor with a chip area of 0.005 mm², power consumption of 0.486 μW at 100 kHz, and enhanced security measures.

Results and Key Outcomes

The project achieved significant advancements in chaotic communication systems:

  • Phase 1 Results: Demonstrated efficient encryption methods with reduced power and area consumption, outperforming traditional digital encryption methods. Metrics such as power, area, and noise robustness were used to optimize system designs.

  • Phase 2 Achievements: Included the creation of reliable and secure transceivers resistant to both eavesdropping and unauthorized replication. By incorporating memristor-based locking mechanisms, the research provided robust security solutions for applications such as wearable and implantable medical devices.

  • Phase 3: Machine learning algorithms successfully enhanced synchronization and error correction in chaos-based encryption systems. SVM and AdaBoost delivered the most promising results, achieving Mean Squared Errors (MSEs) of 5.25 and 3.52, respectively.

  • Phase 4: Successfully transitioned chaos-based encryption designs from FPGA to 45nm CMOS technology. Developed a low-power, area-efficient encryption architecture leveraging Chua’s chaotic equations, suitable for resource-constrained environments. Physical Unclonable Functions (PUFs) demonstrated significant potential for enhancing security through randomness and resilience against physical tampering.

Training and Professional Development

This project played a pivotal role in promoting STEM education and professional development:

  • Diversity Engagement: Female and Hispanic students were actively involved through programs like HSI-STEM, UROP, and BUILD, contributing to increased diversity in engineering.

  • Workshops and Sessions: "Security for Resource Limited Devices" at Grace Hopper Celebration (September 2023), "How AI Affects Innovation" (September 2023): Sponsored by Microsoft Inc, "Artificial Intelligence" Panel at the Beach Women in Engineering Conference (April 2024), Faculty Workshop on AI and Biotechnology Applications at the 37th CSU Biotechnology Symposium (January 2025)

  • Academic Integration: Research outcomes were incorporated into academic courses like EE 532, offering students hands-on learning experiences

Dissemination of Results

The findings were widely disseminated through various channels:

  • Conferences: Presentations at the IEEE Symposium on Hardware Oriented Security and Trust, DATE, IEEE Dallas Circuits and Systems, IEEE Green Energy and Smart System Conference, Silicon Valley Cybersecurity Conference, and the WISE Conference 2024 at the IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center.
  • Outreach Initiatives: Programs like "Women Engineers at the Beach Day" engaged K-12 students, exposing them to advanced engineering concepts and encouraging future STEM careers.
  • Publications: IEEE Access, Discover Internet of Things.

Conclusion

This project successfully combined theoretical advancements in chaos theory with practical hardware implementations, addressing pressing challenges in secure communication and hardware security. By integrating innovative designs with impactful outreach and education, the research not only advanced the field but also contributed to societal progress. The outcomes underscore the importance of interdisciplinary research and its potential for real-world applications.
